title: Studevs
slogan: From curious learners to tech visionaries.
descripcionBreve: A launchpad turning curious CS students into tech builders.
proposito: To unlock top-tier experiences and growth through tech challenges.
inicio: Started after our first hackathon, fueled by the desire to do more.
historiaBreve: I founded Studevs with my friends at 19 when I realized no one was going to open doors for us, so I kicked them open. In one year, we turned a small hackathon squad into a 160+ member launchpad. Now, our alumni are working at top tech companies, winning national competitions, and building products that matter. Studevs wasn’t a club. It was a rebellion.

title: STEP
slogan: Making a change, step by step.
descripcionBreve: A non-profit, youth-run movement I founded at 15 to catalyze sustainable habits in San Luis Potosí. We organized cleanups, collection drives, reforestations, and public awareness—plus built a simple website for recruitment and reporting.
proposito: Reduce local ecological footprint while building an action-first mindset in students and neighbors: see a problem → act → measure → share.
inicio: It was sparked by walking SLP streets and seeing cigarette butts, plastics, and batteries piling up. No teen-led org was converting that frustration into structured, repeatable action. I rallied friends, designed a brand, and started executing weekly..
historiaBreve: At 15, I stopped waiting for permission and started STEP. We mixed small, doable rituals (street sweeps, drop-boxes) with bigger moments (marches, reforestations, talks). Partnerships with schools and local agencies gave us reach; simple brand assets and a website made us legible. In ~18 months, STEP moved from an idea to measurable impact—and taught me how to turn values into execution.

title: Por Una Sonrisa
slogan: Make the difference, it's enough for at least a smile.
descripcionBreve: A 12-week, five-school drive to collect plastic caps and toys; all donations delivered to AMANC SLP and a girls’ shelter. (No software component in this initiative.)
proposito: Turn simple actions (save caps, donate toys) into measurable support for children in need.
inicio: Started after the desire to help people who need it, sparked by the goal of reaching a minimum target of 28 kg of caps felt under-ambitious; we tested whether disciplined cadence + clear comms could 10× outcomes..
historiaBreve: At 16, I was a social activist hungry to help in many ways while learning about the world—and determined to turn that passion into something concrete. I set a three-month plan, recruited five schools, and standardized containers, weekly pickups, and campus owners. We tracked progress, closed cleanly, and ended with two holiday events that made the impact tangible. The lesson: channel conviction into an operating rhythm people can join.

title: Coordinación estudiantil CSA
descripcionBreve: A student-run coordination “by students, for students” that I founded and presided over in high school to amplify student voice, enable freedom of expression, and activate campus culture through officially sanctioned events and a formal dialogue channel with school leadership (Catholic Mothers association).
proposito: Create a legitimate, sustainable space where students can propose, express, and run cultural initiatives with clear rules, fast approvals, and institutional backing.
inicio: At the beginning it was not recognized student body with a clear voice and approval pathway. Cultural ideas died in ad-hoc attempts or bureaucracy. The school needed a reliable bridge between students and the Catholic Mothers leadership to address expression and culture constructively. That's why we wanted a change
historiaBreve: I saw student expression fragmented by unclear processes. I proposed CSA, aligned on a mission with school leadership, and introduced a simple operating rhythm so ideas could move from proposal to stage. With that system, we delivered two emblematic events and—more importantly—left a structure new cohorts could inherit and improve. Today CSA still operates under a new name with the same purpose.

title: SkinScan
slogan: Identify Skin cancer with a photo
descripcionBreve: A machine-learning pipeline and product prototype that classifies 7 skin-lesion categories from dermoscopic images using a MobileNetV2-inspired CNN (standard conv → inverted residual + expansion → GAP → dense; 224×224 input). Includes dataset re-balancing, training/eval code, and a Flutter front-end prototype..
proposito: Offer an accessible screening aid (not a diagnosis) to flag likely classes and help clinicians/learners prioritize follow-up.
inicio: It began as a student project, we started with a public datasets are heavily imbalanced, undermining generalization. The client needed a defensible pipeline + usable UI to accompany a research write-up. Constraint: deliver a demo-grade product with clear disclaimers in 4 months.
historiaBreve: We turned a client brief into a shippable plan: fix the data balance, keep the model lean, and ship a demo that a clinician can understand at a glance. I led PM cadence across four teammates, translated requirements into acceptance criteria, and pushed the pipeline, Flutter UI, and research figures forward in parallel. In four months we had a balanced dataset, a reproducible CNN, a usable prototype, and a paper-ready narrative—validated by a national win.

title: Edu-ard
slogan: AI that learns your students—so you can lead them better.
descripcionBreve: A hackathon-built platform where professors create syllabus-aligned chatrooms and students join with unique IDs to ask questions they might hesitate to ask in class. Edu-ard’s AI analyzes conversations to surface class insights (topics of confusion, sentiment, participation patterns) so instructors can adapt teaching.
proposito: Create a safe, structured channel for student questions and turn those signals into actionable, instructor-level insights (what to revisit, who’s stuck, where to scaffold).
inicio: We observed how students routinely hold back questions in traditional settings, professors lack continuous, granular feedback between exams.
historiaBreve: We traveled to Monterrey for HackMTY and scoped a problem we’d felt firsthand: students hold back, and professors fly blind between exams. In ~3 hours I designed the end-to-end brand and flows, then implemented most of the frontend so the team could demo live. Edu-ard lets professors spin up syllabus-aligned rooms while students engage safely; the AI layer turns conversations into teaching cues—a lightweight loop from question → insight → better class.
